name: Notes on K-pop
description: An essay / annotated bibliography collating some thoughts about k-pop, marketing, and fandoms. Written for Syllabus Project

name: Unseen Garden (sound)
description: Generative sound programming forUnseen Garden, a project by Chris Hamamoto and Federico Perez Villoro. More about the project here.

name: Toward Frisson
description: An archive of 2-word poems, collected over several years, displayed on screen and in print. Created for Unrealized Archive 7L Text to Image, an exhibition put on by Chris Hamamoto & Jon Sueda at wrm in Seoul, Korea

name: Trekker / Browser
description: A website / type specimen created for Occupant Fonts to showcase their typefaces Stainless 2 and Dispatch 2.

name: ASDFGHJKLKGJL
description: An essay about fandoms and fan shrines for are.na. Special Thanks to Meg Miller for editing.

name: Pentameter (sound)
description: Sound design for pentad.world, a type specimen website for Occupant Font's typeface, Pentameter. Website designed by Laurel Schwulst. (Read more about it here!). Typeface and web programming by Marie Otsuka.

name: Lore
description: Research and writing about internet lore and online cultural production as part of Other Internet.

name: Transparencia Index
description: Web Development and design for Transparencia index, a project by Federico Pérez Villoro. The web scraper and database was developed by Agnes Cameron. It was commissioned by Printed Matter + EXILE Books for NADA Miami 2021.

name: Falsa Poesia
description: Poster design and website creation for Falsa poesía: el tallo de las flores cruje, a project by Federico Pérez Villoro. The website was used in a performative reading of a body of AI-generated poetry, which is also featured on the poster.

name: LP—20x20
description: A Website I made for 20 friends to share 20 songs they discovered in 2020. Built using Angular

name: Flower Fields
description: Two clocks:
1. Flower Field
2. Pluses

name: Reading Machines
description: An ongoing publishing platform to reimagine established relationships between reader, text, and author, and to fully utilize the affordances the web offers in the presentation of text. Contributors are asked to submit texts that might lend themselves well to non-linear readings, which are then re-interpreted into their own websites.
If you are interested in contributing, inquire by emailing tiger.dingsun@gmail.com

name: Cross Chancery
description: A variable typeface based on the idea of pixellating a traditional chancery typeface.

The typeface varies on two axes: 1) The pixel shape interpolates from a cross shape, a clover shape, and a spike shape. 2) The pixels themselves interpolate from the chancery formation to becoming more diffuse to becoming a box formation
To inqure about use, email tiger.dingsun@gmail.com
Cross Chancery in Use: [1], [2]

name: Words So Beautiful To Look At
description: 22"x35" RISO poster, printed by folding a large sheet of butcher paper into fourths and printing on each section separately. Printed in two editions of Teal/Fluorescent Pink, and Gold/Fluorescent Pink.
This poster is about the graphic and sensory quality of words.

Words produce meaning not only through their semiotic function to merely point to some concept in the world, but also their multisensory function, creating (weak) synesthetic relationships between the word and different colors, sounds, smells, tastes, and textures. Even the visuality of the word itself—not necessarily the typographic choices used to render it, but the actual shape of the words and base letterforms themselves—can be regarded as objects with aesthetic values. Moreover, grouping words together in order to appeal to some historical or social taxonomy or system of classification creates further resonance between, drawing from shared cultural systems of knowledge.

name: Chimeric Worlding
description: An Essay and collection of 12 conceptual graphic design exercises titled 'Chimeric Worlding: What Can Graphic Design Learn from Poetics and World-building?'
Key Words: Poetics, World-Building, Structure, Mythos, Narrative, Ambiguity, Epistemic Disobedience, Non-Teleological Reading.

name: I Never Want to See the Same Image Twice
description: A series of 18 websites that explore different ways of presenting text, narrative, and poetry in digital space. Can text be ambient? Non-linear? Performed by a website? Performed by user interaction?
PDF of print documentation

name: Sound and Vision
description: Work created with Max/MSP during Winter 2019
1. Unincorporated Territory

Based on the movie Brokeback Mountain, two separate texts of different lengths cycle through on the top and bottom of the videos, constantly creating new meanings. The subjectivity of the cowboy is interesting to me because it seems to be the locus of both colonial fantasy and homoeroticism.
2. A Day at the Beach

An instrument for reading and writing semi-improvisationally. The three windows are dragged and resized to reveal more of the text that exists on an underlying hidden matrix. The performer is meant to constantly reposition the windows to create new tones and new meanings, while also writing in a loose way that responds to the text that is already on the screen.
3. One Common Red Flat Sharp

Lists of sensorial words come together. Words that look good, that sound good, that smell good. In pairs, they flash on screen to create a rapid fire sequence of short 'reading events' — moments of minor synesthesia. Typeset in Corpus Regular, designed by me

name: Corpus
description: Corpus is a text weight typeface based on 'Beijing Comrades,' an erotic gay novel published anonymously in China on the Internet in 1998. Its steep serifs and supple curves evoke the the danger and allure of homo-romanticism in the midst of China's rapid economic development.
Email me at tiger.dingsun@gmail.com if you are interested in using this typeface!

name: A Lexicon of Hesitation
description: A poster created for a performance created with Federico Perez Villoro. Illustrations by Ana Rivera, Typography by me.
Performed/Displayed at Paul Kasmin Gallery (NYC) in the summer of 2018, as part of the exhibition 'Almost Solid Light: New Work From Mexico.'
